stem: An 80-year-old client is brought in by his daughter for a 6-month history of 'acting strange.' Based on the documentation in the Geriatric Cognitive & Mobility Differential tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Progressive decline in gait and cognition.
Background: No history of stroke. Lives at home.
Assessment: Client has a wide-based gait and seems to 'glue' his feet to the floor. Daughter says he has started 'wetting the bed.'
Recommendation: Large-volume lumbar puncture trial.

tabs.title: Cognitive & Mobility Differential
tabs.content:
Condition TriadCurrent FindingInterpretation
Wobbly (Gait)Wide-based; 'Magnet gait'Frontal lobe compression
Wacky (Cognition)Mild memory loss; Slowed thinkingDementia mimic
Wet (Incontinence)Frequent urinary accidentsSphincter control loss
CT BrainVentricle enlargement out of proportion to atrophyHydrocephalus suspected

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 128/78, HR 72, RR 16, T 98.4°F. Client is AO x 2.

actionOptions.text: Assess the client's gait before and after a large-volume Lumbar Puncture (LP)
Provide safety education and implement fall precautions
Encourage the client to drink 3 liters of water to increase CSF pressure

parameterOptions.text: Gait stability and urinary continence status
Level of orientation and short-term memory improvement
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) (c2), identified by the classic clinical triad: 'Wet, Wacky, and Wobbly' (Incontinence, Cognitive decline, and Magnet Gait). Unlike standard hydrocephalus, the ICP is technically normal, but the fluid accumulation still compresses the brain. The diagnostic test is a large-volume LP (a1) to see if symptoms improve; if they do, a VP shunt is placed. Fall precautions (a2) are critical due to the magnetic gait. Parameters focus on the 'Triad' recovery (p1, p2).
clinicalPearls: NPH is a treatable/reversible cause of dementia symptoms in the elderly.
Magnet Gait: The client's feet seem stuck to the floor, like magnets.
The 'Wet' (incontinence) usually develops last in the triad.

questionTrap.trap: Calling this 'Alzheimer's' because the patient is 80 and confused.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Alzheimer's does NOT typically cause a wide-based 'magnet' gait or sudden incontinence early on. If you see all three 'W' signs, think NPH.
